advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #5 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> I LEARN AT SCHOOL</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for the new model, dated april 1986. <br><br> "I learn at school, I rock at home"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (NOV. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says that 37 cartridges are already available and that a BASIC programming cartridge is on the way (though it will never make it to the shelves). <br><br> The advert also clearly says that the system comes from America and that it offers Arcade Hits at home.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ALTAIR CONVENTION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Altair Convention was here announced in the Computer Notes magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Mark Thompson</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Yes, it's really him – William Shatner (Captain Kirk).<br> Did they really use VIC-20 in the Enterprise?<br> That would certainly explain a lot of things...<p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Isn't this a stupid advert ?!<br> Look carefully at each face !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"With the Alice computer, you place the level where you want"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>First advert of the Model 100.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR TECHNOLOGIES CREATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The conbination of Victor Business Products and Sirius Systems Technology Inc. creates a new company designed to meet the most demanding needs of the modern business office...<br> ... The result is Victor Technologies Inc., a company idally suited to dramatically impact today's international computer marketplace.<br><br> The Chairman of the board of the new Victor Technologies in Fred Sullivan, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kiddle, Inc., a diversified $3 billion company. The financial support of this giant conglomerate will help focus Victor's goal of becoming one of the three leading computer companies in the world.<br> President and Chief Executive Officer of the new company is Chuck Peddle. Acknowledged as the "father" of the personal computer concept, Peddle introduced this useful and very affordable third generation micro-computer in the European market with startling results..</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... With the knowledge that Mitsubishi is the largest manufacturer of Mainframe computers in Japan, those in the know will immediately recognise the true potential of the Mitsubishi F-series...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #6 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The new sale price is $99.95 instead of 149.95 <br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The ZX81 represents the latest technology in microelectronics. More than 10,000 are sold every week. In fact, the ZX81 is the best selling personal computer in the world.</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (JUNE 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil presents its software" <br><br> - S.BASIC programming language<br> - SPG2 accounting / management software<br> - VOLTAIRE word processing</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OEMS WANTED</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
The Epoch TV Baseball is an early japanese video-game released in 1978. It is a stand-alone system, as it can play only one game: baseball!
Indeed, baseball has always been very popular in Japan. It was logic that it inspired first videogames there.
The game can be played by two players, one launching the ball and the other manipulating the bat. There is a detachable controller with only one fire button, and all the other controls are on the system itself.
It is interesting to note that this baseball game is apparently the same (?) found on cartridge for the Epoch Cassette Vision.
computer.keyboard: One detachable controller (fire button) + controls built-in the system (dial, buttons, switches)
computer.name: TV Baseball
